docs.title: 0PN Lab Specs
docs.text:
Welcome to the 0PN Lab GitHub, focused on Digital Public Transparency Infrastructure (DPTI). This repository supports implementing the Convention 108+ Code of Conduct through an extension profile that publishes the 0PN Lab ISO/IEC TS 27560 profile lineage and the consolidated “Digital Consent” packaging, based on the ISO/IEC 27560 consent record information structure.

How to use this site - If you want the best overview, start with DCR v1.2. - If you want the most stable implementer reference, start with UNR v1.01. - Treat v1.1 as a working draft unless you are participating in a pilot or review.

docs.title: What this standard provides
docs.text: ISO/IEC TS 27560:2023 specifies an interoperable, open, and extensible information structure for recording a PII principal’s consent to PII processing, supporting: - provision of a record to the PII principal - exchange of consent information between information systems - management of the life cycle of the recorded consent

docs.title: How this repo extends it
docs.text: The 0PN Lab profile lineage in this repository extends ISO/IEC TS 27560:2023 toward Transparency-by-Default infrastructure by adding (at the profile layer): - Controller-ID first disclosure before collection or inference - Bilateral proof-of-notice patterns (receipts held by both controller and individual) - A consolidated “Digital Consent” packaging (DCR v1.2) built on the UNR lineage

docs.title: OCV — Operational Constraint Vocabulary
docs.text: Supporting vocabulary for expressing operational constraints and interoperability rules

docs.title: What this is
docs.text: OCV provides vocabulary support for expressing constraints that matter operationally (for example: scope, context, applicability, and enforcement-oriented conditions) alongside the profile lineage.

docs.title: How it relates to this repo
docs.text: OCV is a supporting component used to keep: - profile requirements expressible in machine-consumable form - constraints inspectable and testable - implementations consistent across domains and jurisdictions

Code of Conduct Profile packaging built on the UNR profile lineage

docs.title: What v1.2 is
docs.text: v1.2 consolidates the UNR lineage into a single packaging framed as Digital Consent (Code of Conduct Profile), centered on: - Controller-ID first disclosure before collection or inference - Bilateral proof-of-notice (two-party receipts) - State tracking and material change visibility (notice event logs) - Portability and rights-control patterns where applicable, without surveillance intermediaries

docs.title: UNR v1 — Universal Notice Receipt (Submission Draft)
docs.text:
ISO/IEC 27560 profile contribution (submission draft PDF)

Status: Submission draft (historical anchor) Note: This is a submission artefact and should be treated as non-normative unless explicitly adopted in a formal standards track.

docs.title: What this version is
docs.text: UNR v1 establishes the initial profile layer that extends the ISO/IEC TS 27560 base structure into a Transparency-by-Default architecture, centered on: - Controller-ID first disclosure (before collection or inference) - Bilateral notice receipts (proof held by both controller and individual) - A pathway toward notice event logs and progressive assurance levels

docs.title: Recommended reading path
docs.text: If you want the most stable implementer reference, start with: - UNR v1.01 baseline: https://github.com/0PN-lab/specs/blob/e19ad403f5ee6a200ff65d02913fd854243b356f/27560%20profile%20/v%201.01%20-%20UNR%20-%20Notice%20Receipt/ISO-IEC-27560-1-v1.01.md

docs.title: UNR v1.01 — Universal Notice Receipt Profile (Baseline)
docs.text:
Best starting point for stable interpretation and implementer reference

Status: Baseline internal draft (v1.01) Use case: Recommended reference when you need the UNR architecture without draft churn.

docs.title: What this version is
docs.text: UNR v1.01 is the baseline profile reference that operationalises: - Controller-ID first disclosure - Stage-based exchange (Stage 1 notice receipt as the minimal base pattern) - Bilateral proof-of-notice and auditability primitives that enable Code of Conduct style governance

docs.title: How to use this page
docs.text:
• If you are implementing or reviewing “UNR as prerequisite infrastructure,” use v1.01 as the stable baseline.
  • If you are evaluating enhancements, proceed to v1.1 as a working draft.
  • If you are using the consolidated packaging, proceed to DCR v1.2.

docs.title: UNR v1.1 — Universal Notice Receipt Profile (Working Draft)
docs.text:
Enhancement set (pilot only)

Status: Working draft Warning: v1.1 may change and may include incomplete or non-renderable artefacts depending on file format.

docs.title: What this version is
docs.text: UNR v1.1 is the working-draft enhancement set that expands the baseline profile toward: - Privacy preference signal handling (for example GPC) - Digital transparency risk assurance levels - Rights automation patterns (where applicable) - Token and exchange extensions (where applicable) - AI transparency extensions (where applicable)

docs.title: How this fits the v1.2 consolidation
docs.text:
DCR v1.2 consolidates UNR v1 + v1.01 + v1.1 into a single “Digital Consent” packaging.

  • DCR v1.2 consolidated: https://github.com/0PN-lab/specs/blob/bd54d86fe8d063b6f935f1adf5cadb6adf85f928/27560%20profile%20/v%201.2%20-%20Digital%20Notice%20%26%20Consent%20Profile%20/v1.2%20-%20Digital%20Consent%20(consolidated).md

docs.title: What this page is
docs.text: This page documents the well-known discovery pattern used to publish controller disclosure artefacts (for example a Controller Identification Record and related transparency metadata) at a predictable path on a controller domain.

docs.title: Why it matters
docs.text: Well-known locations enable: - automated discovery by individuals, regulators, and agents - verification before collection (Controller-ID first ordering) - consistent cross-controller interoperability without bespoke integrations
